title: Releasing Search Queries and Clicks Privately

author: Aleksandra Korolova, Computer Science Department, Stanford University
Krishnaram Kenthapadi, Microsoft Research
Nina Mishra, Microsoft Research
Alexandros Ntoulas, Microsoft Research

segmentation: By Alexander Corle, over which is a PhD student and Stanford University.
And the talk is about releasing search queries and clicks privately.
Hi everyone, I'm Alexandra.

I'm going to be talking about releasing search queries and clicks privately and this is joint work with Krishna, Ram, Counterparty, Neena, Mishra, an Alex and tools from Microsoft Research Search Labs so.
Why really search logs all of us who don't work for a search engine would love to have access to search logs because they contain so much interesting information from so many different perspectives.
Those of us who do algorithmic research would love to work on improving many of the algorithmic and data mining techniques those of us could do.
Linguistics would love to see what kind of things people search for an what language do they use, if you are.
An advertiser or on line website you would love to have access to query logs in order to be able to improve advertising or to understand what kind of keywords the users use to get to your web page.
And the only.
From one perspective, the search engines would love to also release the search logs in order to get the other people to help them develop new algorithms.

An improved the algorithms that exist and also to share the wealth of information that they have with wider research and academic community and the the problem with doing that is that people post painfully private information, private questions to the search engine.
Because they implicitly assume that whatever they posted to the search engine is between them and the search engine, they.
Most people don't even realize that the search engine is logging every query that they pose, and they much less.

Do they think that this might ever be released and be available to somebody other than the search engine and some of the queries that people who pose is asking for their Social Security number, which is a very private piece of information.

In the United States and they ask it just to see whether that information is out there and other queries that they pose is looking for their financial information, their credit card number, the phone number as well as some of the other things that they're concerned about.
So for instance, if they have or suspect they have some disease, they look for things that might be the symptoms of that disease, or look for other people who might have such such a disease.
And so forth.
What?
Has been done previously in order to find out whether one can release their search logs.
One approach that was taken by AOL in 2006 was to say the following.

Well, let us let us remove the IP addresses from the logs and replace the IP addresses with a randomized ID that has no relation to the user ID, and then hopefully that would be protection enough to anonymize the user from being deciphered.
And here you have.
If you look at the slide you have some examples of queries by.
One user who whose queries were released in such a way by AOL, and Imagine that you're trying to break this person's privacy.
If I ask you what's, what's the age of this person?
Can you based on these queries that you see?
Can you venture a guess?
60 yes, so the 60 single men and clothes for 60 plus age suggests that this person might be 60.
If I ask you what's the gender of this person, can you venture a guess?
Female.
Why female?
Well?
Because she's looking for a single man and because she's looking for plastic surgeons.
Maybe it's not so for sure that it's a female.
Maybe there are some.
Chances are male, but you know with higher probability is a female.
If I asked you to say where this where does this person live?
Can you venture guess for that?
Alright, so one guess would be Lilburn GA because the the person is looking for landscapers there.
Another guess would be Eugene OR or Gwinnett County in Georgia.
And finally, if I asked you what do you think this person's last name is, can you venture a guess for that?
I know yes, so maybe, maybe not, but one can guess that perhaps it's Arnold.
So the New York Times Reporter did exactly what we just did here and went through the elag release that way and found that indeed this person is a female.
She is 62 years old.
Her name is Thelma Arnold and she lives in Limbo, Georgia, and there were many other queries that were posed by this user.
So tell us Fillmore wasn't thrilled.
To see that now the whole world knows that she's searching for the dog, urinates on anything, and this also had a very negative outcome for AOL.
So those.
Not not.
Not a good move.
They were.
Other approaches proposed and people have been actively thinking about what else you can do in order to analyze the logs.
One approach is to say well.
In the previous example, the reason we were able to be anonymize who this user was is because there were names that were locations.
There were dates and so forth.
So why don't we just go ahead, remove all the names, dates, locations or all the numbers from the log and hope that this would?

Protect privacy and the problem with that approach is that we don't always know what's the name or what's a location, or if it's a name is that private name that one would remove, or is a search such as Barack Obama not private and OK to leave inside the lock?
There was another approach proposed by Kumar Tile in www.twoyearsago where they said, well, the next intuitive thing to do is to hash.
Each token that occurs in the search log and instead of releasing the the the words released their hashes and that should be.

It should be private, but what they said what they found out what they showed in their work is that actually that's not true, because if you have access to some other source of data, such as the previously released AOL log, then you can look at frequency of the words that occur in this other source of data and correlated with.
Frequency of the hashes and you can invert the hash that way and it turned out that celebrity names were very helpful in inverting the hash, so this also doesn't work.
Another suggestion that you commonly hear from just people thinking about this question is to say, well, why don't we just release the frequent queries?
The queries that occur enough times and opposed enough times shouldn't be that private, and I'm going to come back to this suggestion later in the talk.
One thing that one can say is how do you know what's sufficiently frequently posed?

And finally the the problem with all the ad hoc techniques and sort of intuitively saying that if we do this and it's going to be private enough, is that we never know what other sources of information the attacker is going to have access to.
And maybe the attacker will be able to stitch together different sources of information in order to later break the privacy.

And the goal of our work is to figure out whether we can really search logs in such a way that we have provable privacy guarantees so we can prove rigorously that it satisfies privacy and also at the same time we want to release the log so that they still are useful to all the people who want to get access to them.
And I'm going to answer positively to both these questions in this talk, so first.
Well, if we want to be able to give provable privacy guarantees, we need a formal privacy definition that we aim to satisfy, and some of the.
Things that we might like to have in this privacy definition is not to make any unnecessary assumptions.
So for instance, we don't want to make any assumptions on the types of knowledge that the attacker might have or the other datasets that the attacker might have access to.
We also don't want to make any assumptions on the computational power of the advertiser, and Furthermore, we don't want to make any assumptions on the users, so I don't want to assume that each user.
Search is in a certain way or assume that certain queries I in intrinsically private and I private because for some people, perhaps their sexual orientation is private and for others they don't.
Consider that the private information, so I don't want to assume anything about that.

Unfortunately, there is a formal privacy definition that has been gaining prominence in the cryptography and security community in the last couple years that achieves all that, and it's called different.
So privacy I'm not gonna give a formal definition and write out the formulas of what differential privacy states.
I'm just going to try to give you some intuition of what it says.
So suppose you are the Prince of Astoria, and suppose you don't use any search engine.

Then if there is some search log and then there's some randomized release algorithm that releases some part of the search log and the attacker looks at this release data set, then maybe he gets some knowledge about the Prince.
But you know it's not anything posed by the Prince.
Now suppose that you think oh, Now suppose that the Prince wants to use a search engine, and maybe he does an if he uses a search search engine.
And then there's again a randomized release that happens to and then the attacker looks at the release data set.
Then he also get some knowledge about the Prince.

So the randomized release algorithm A. Satisfies differential privacy if the knowledge that the attacker gets by looking at the release data set in the case when the Prince is using the search engine is roughly the same as the knowledge that that I can get by looking at the release data set.

If the if the Prince is not using the search engine, so essentially it says that the risk the ones privacy increases only slightly from using the search engine and then in terms of differential privacy you can go and.

Go ahead and quantify what does it mean that the risk increases only slightly in terms of two parameters, epsilon or Delta, and roughly speaking epsilon is the multiplicative increase in the risk to your privacy and Delta is an additive increase in the risk to the privacy and the privacy definition guarantees this not just for the Prince but also for any person who can potentially be using the search engine.
And here's our approach given this privacy definition.
First of all, we reframe the question a little bit.
We look at the way that the search logs are commonly used and say, well the search lock has a lot of information and we can't release all of it.
But we're going to focus on a certain part of the search lock called the query click graph and the query click craft will consists of nodes and edges.
The nodes are the queries and the URL's and the query click.
Life also has the count for the number of times each query was posed.
And the count for the number of clicks each URL received, given that that query was post an.
Although the query click graph is not as rich source of data as the search and sort of the full search engine log, it can still be used for many of our motivating applications.

So now I'm going to show you how we're gonna release the query click graph in a way that satisfies privacy and I'm going to start by showing how we can release the queries in the way that satisfies privacy.
So first of all, we're going to look at each query an we're gonna count how many times this query occurs in the search log, and once we counted it, we're gonna add it to the account for each query.

Some noise of from Laplace distribution to obtain the so-called noisy count of the number of occurrences of this query, and then we're going to look at whether this noisy count exceeds a specified threshold, and if it does exceed the specified threshold, then we're going to determine that the query and it's noisy count.
Are OK to be released an if it doesn't exceed the threshold, then we're going to conclude that it's not OK to be released.
And both the Laplace distribution and the specified threshold at determined by their desired privacy guarantees.
So they are determined by the Epsilon and Delta that we want to achieve in our privacy definition.

And this algorithm also sort of settles the question of what if you released only the sufficient frequent queries?
Would that be private?

And what can we release?
We can release about 2.5 million distinct queries, which constitutes about 3.5 billion impressions.

That's something and some of the queries that work that could be releasable under this algorithm is, for instance, how to tie a Windsor knot or vintage aluminum Christmas trees so they're nice long queries.
They're nontrivial.
Movie.
Can't do an an application that one might want to use the queries for one application that we chose from social science is studying peoples fears.

So there there have been a lot of surveys trying to quantify what are the most frequent fears and one of the surveys we looked at is a phone survey that comes up with a list of the top nine fears as reported by people through a survey of bill cancer in his 2008 book click.
And proposed another way to get at this information.
They he said that people probably search for their fears on the search engine.
And if we looked at the fear of queries in the search logs then we can have another list of what are the most frequent fears.
And looking at that you get another list and you could see that the the answer of what are the most frequent fears?
If you look at the queries versus if you look at the phone survey is very different.

For instance, if you look at social fears, then there are about four social fears that people search for in the top nine fears, whereas there are only two social fears that people report and one explanation for that is that people might be more comfortable searching for something like fear of public speaking or fear of abandonment of fear of intimacy when they think that is between them in the search engine versus when they're answering on the phone to another person.

We repeated this experiment looking at the release queries so that the queries that can be released using our algorithm and what we find is that the the top nine list of the queries is about the same both when you look at the original search log and when you look at the releasable queries, there were some permutation in the frequencies of what are the top most fears.
So the first most common fear is the fear of flying in both cases.
A fear of Heights.
In both cases a second public speaking is a little bit shifted from 5th to 2nd to third position, but the list is roughly the same.

And what's even more interesting is that the social fears are still all there, so if anything, the data that can be released by our algorithm can be used as a great source for finding new questions to pose in social science or exploring other directions that you otherwise don't have access to.
Finally, we look at an algorithmic application that that uses a query click graph, and.
The algorithmic application is recommending keywords to online advertisers, so suppose you're an advertiser and you want to launch an on line ad campaign around the concept.
Suppose you're Travelocity and you want to you know your Travelocity.
You might have some idea about what are the keyboards that people would use when searching for you, but you would like to find other keyboards that could be useful.
An approach for doing that is using a random walk on the query click graph, which was proposed by Foxman at all at last year's www.
So what we do is we repeat their algorithm of the random walk both on the original search log and privately releasable query, click graph and compare the performance.
And here is the Top 40 suggestions that you get for Travelocity on the original search graph.
Maybe it's a little bit hard to see, but roughly what you get is various misspellings of the word Travelocity from from simple ones like 1L instead of or two hours instead of 1.
Two more complicated ones as travel and velocity as two different words, and you also get some non trivial queries like last minute travel.
World vacation packages.
As a suggestions now, if you look at the the query keyword suggestions generated from a private private block, you get about 13 to 15% of the total number that you could get from the original lock.
And sure, that's fewer, but that's the price to pay for privacy in some sense.
And also if you look at the Top 40 keywords generated.
That way you can see that there are roughly the same.

So in the Top 40 list or there were 37 keyword suggestions that overlap and in from when you start from the private query click graph, you missed three of the suggestions from the original lock and you get three others instead.
So our we also did this for other seed sets and so forth and the results were roughly similar.
In conclusion, what have we achieved so we?
Pulled an algorithm for releasing queries and clicks with provable privacy guarantees.
We showed that a nontrivial amount of queries and impressions and clicks can be released, and we also gave some evidence that the release data preserves utility.
We quantified the folklore notion of releasing the frequent queries works, and we kind of modified that to show how would how that would work if you wanted to do it.
And finally, mostly in the paper, we explored the tradeoffs between privacy and utility and the privacy parameters and the utility you would get from this rich logs.
In terms of future work, one of the things that we'd like to do is to capture a little bit more of the tail.
Then we are able to capture right now, and perhaps that can be achieved by grouping similar queries from the tail.
Considering their total count and releasing just annoys account of that, and maybe hoping that this way it would get over the threshold.

The other open question is to figure out how to choose the privacy parameters in practice so the differential privacy definition is very robust in the sense that it has a way to two and the privacy parameters that you desire.
But there is an open question as to what those privacy parameters should be if you were to go ahead and release a search log indeed.
And finally, there is much more through search engine lock release than the privacy of users.
There is also privacy of the search engine and also privacy.
Perhaps of the advertisers or the the companies whose things are listed in the query click graph and that's something that we'd like to address as well.

Pulled an algorithm for releasing queries and clicks with provable privacy guarantees.
We showed that a nontrivial amount of queries and impressions and clicks can be released, and we also gave some evidence that the release data preserves utility.
We quantified the folklore notion of releasing the frequent queries works, and we kind of modified that to show how would how that would work if you wanted to do it.
